comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: I don't think that's the USS Michigan. She had two funnels, and main armament in 4 turrets. Instead, I believe this is a battleship of the Virginia class of predreadnought battleships, based on the 3 funnels and double-story gun turrets. Also, the ship on the right looks like a French cruiser, based on the disposition of the funnels, and shape of the turrets. USS Michigan: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Michigan_(BB-27) Virginia class: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_class_battleship

comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: After further research, the French cruiser at right appears to be from the Gueydon class: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gueydon_class_cruiser

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content:
definitely, the 3 funnels, the cranes, and the turret shape eliminate any other class.  All 5 from the class served at Veracruz, so it would be hard to say which it was, 

USS Virginia
USS Nebraska
USS Georgia
USS New Jersey
USS Rhode Island
they got cage masts in 1909

one of her sister appears to be on the extreme upper left as well

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: USS Michigan definitely was at Vera Cruz in April-June, 1914. The Michigan's presence there could have caused confusion that led the Bain News Agency to mis-identify the ship in the photo.

comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: Aside from the fact that USS Michigan only had 2 funnels, and the ship in this photo has 3, also note the shape of the cranes for the ship's boats. This ship has curved ones, while the Michigan had straight ones. I'm 99% certain this is not USS Michigan in the photo.

comment.author: 24583408@N02
comment._content: Ship in question is definitely not USS Michigan, Kilted cowboy is correct, It is one of Virginia clas BB's , there were five, take your pick.

comment.author: 7471115@N08
comment._content: I wish the LIbrary of Congress would correct the title on this. :)
